title: Latex equations for biologists from A to Z
description: From "density dependent growth" to "matrix population model".
contents:
I’m working on a book project called “Ecology
For All!” and spending a lot of time writing equations in latex. I
write up equations like this maybe once a year and have to review every
time what to do, and spend time knocking the code around to get what I
want.
There are many good introductions to Latex and Latex equations out
there. Below, I present just a working list of common equations in
biology.
A very brief primer of
Latex equations
There are two ways to present Latex equation: inline
and display. Inline equations appear in a line of
normal text, like this: \(\lambda =
\frac{N_{t+1}}{N_t}\). Display mode equations appear on a
separate line:
\[\lambda =
\frac{N_{t+1}}{N_t}\]
The only difference between inline and display markdown up is the
inline is preceded by \( and closed by \),
while display mode is preceded by \[ and closed by
\].
In an Rmarkdown document inline equations can therefore be included
like this:
text text text\(\lambda = \frac{N_{t+1}}{N_t}\) text
text
This will be rendered as
text text text \(\lambda =
\frac{N_{t+1}}{N_t}\) text text.
Display equation are written like this:
some text
\[\lambda = \frac{N_{t+1}}{N_t}\]
some more text

\beta_1*x_i\)

Solo:
\[y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1*x_i\]

Inline example: \(\frac{N_{t+1}}{N_t}\)

Greek symbols
Greek symbols are invoked via their name, preceded by a slash. \(\alpha\) is therefore genereated via
\(\alpha\). Uppercase, when different than the Enlighs
equivalent, are generated by capitalizing the Greek name: \(\Gamma\) is therefore generated via
\(\Gamma\). When the uppercase Greek and English are the
same the markup for normal text within an equation is used:
\\(\\textrm{Z}\\) yields uppercase Zeta, which is just
\(\textrm{Z}\).

title: Welcome to Computational Biology for All!
description: Welcome to my new blog, Computational Biology for All!
contents:
Welcome to Computational Biology for All. This blog
is dedicated to introducing and explaining quantitative methods to
biologists. Topics will include:
computational biology
bioinformatics
phylogenetics
data science
statistical analysis
simulation
data visualization
To kick off the blog I am going to do a series outlining how to
carryout a common task in molecular biology, bioinformatics, and
evolutionary biology: building a multiple
sequence alignment and phylogenetic
tree using protein sequences obtained from the National Institutes
of Health’s databases.
